HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  This is a 40-year-old male found
down [**Location (un) 108737**]with apparent facial trauma.  The
patient was unresponsive at the scene and intubated by EMS
secondary to a GCS of less than 8.  The patient did have
spontaneous respirations and lower extremity movements noted.
The patient was transported, boarded and collared in the
Emergency Room.  The patient was noted to be moving his left
upper extremity and right foot spontaneously with a GCS for
reevaluation at 7+.  While in the Emergency Room, the patient
received a CT of the head, neck, abdomen and pelvis and a
chest x-ray.  A chest x-ray revealed no pneumothorax.  CT of
the neck showed no fracture, dislocation.  CT of the abdomen
and pelvis showed no intra-abdominal pathology.  Most notable
was a CT of the head which showed extensive facial bone
injuries, including displaced fractures of the anterior and
posterior left maxillary walls, lateral orbital wall, orbital
floor, possibly the medial orbital wall.  There is extensive
hemorrhage inferiorly within the left orbit causing superior
displacement of the inferior rectus muscle and exophthalmos
with an intact globe.  There was, however, no evidence of
intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect.  At this point, the
patient was admitted to the SICU under the trauma service for
continued care with consultation of the ophthalmology service
and plastic surgery.

The patient's initial past medical history and past surgical
history was unknown.  On extubation, past medical history of
severe hypertension noted.  The patient is a homeless
gentleman with severe alcoholism and history of DTs and
polysubstance abuse.

MEDICATION:
1.  Atenolol, unknown dose

ALLERGIES:  LATER NOTED TO BE PENICILLIN, FOR WHICH THE
PATIENT DEVELOPS HIVES.

PHYSICAL EXAM ON ADMISSION:
VITAL SIGNS:  Temperature 98.8??????, pulse of 120, blood pressure
170/palpation, 20 and 98% on vent of 600 x 12.
GENERAL:  The patient was intubated.  Patient with extensive
facial trauma, left facial ecchymosis, edentulous.
HEAD, EARS, EYES, NOSE AND THROAT:  Tympanic membranes were
clear bilaterally.  Right pupil was minimally reactive and
sluggish.  Left pupil 6 mm and reactive.
CHEST:  Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
HEART:  Regular rate and rhythm.
ABDOMEN:  Soft, pelvis stable.
EXTREMITIES:  Without palpable deformities, pulses distally
2+ bilaterally, warm.
RECTAL:  Tone was normal.
BACK:  No apparent stepoff.
NEUROLOGIC:  Patient with spontaneous left hand movements.

ADMISSION LABS:  The patient had a white count of 8,
hematocrit of 44, platelets of 161.  Sodium of 142, potassium
of 4.1, chloride of 102, bicarbonate of 20, BUN of 7,
creatinine of 0.6, sugar of 166.  Fibrinogen was 348.
Amylase was 176.  Arterial blood gases was 7.57, 24, 544, 23
and +2.  Urine toxicology had an alcohol level of 361.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to the SICU
intubated for further evaluation.  The patient's main issues
were his multiple left facial fractures.  On hospital day #2
the patient was extubated.  The patient received an urgent
ophthalmology evaluation, at which point a lateral canthotomy
was performed due to increased intraocular pressure and
orbital pressure and the concern of entrapment.  On hospital
day #2, the patient continued with pain and pressure of the
eye and complaints of withdrawal.  The patient was placed on
the CIWA scale with Ativan to prevent DTs.  After the lateral
canthotomy was performed, the patient was placed on timolol
and Diamox to decrease intraocular pressure.  The patient was
followed by plastics for the extensive orbital fractures, but
ultimately felt that outpatient management of these fractures
could be performed.

On hospital day #3, the spine service was consulted for
spinal clearance and an MRI of the neck was performed.  The
MR of the cervical spine showed suspicion for
intraligamentous injury of the interspinous ligaments of T2
to T3.  In addition, a superficial paraspinal muscular injury
extending to the subcutaneous space at the T2-T3 level,
however no cord compression was seen.  An MR of the head was
also performed at this time which showed no evidence of
subarachnoid hemorrhage.  The area of trauma showed extensive
soft tissue and bony facial injuries with displaced fractures
of anterior and lateral maxillary sinuses.  Left sided
exophthalmos again noted.

Ophthalmology continued to follow the patient.  The patient
was continued on Xalatan to left eye q hs, Alphagan to left
eye b.i.d. and Timoptic to both eyes b.i.d.

On hospital day #4, there is still no evidence of entrapment,
although the patient continued with limited extraocular
movements due to swelling.  His vision remained intact.  He
did, however, have left sided nose numbness.  At this point,
the patient was seen by the orthopedic service and
recommended [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 36323**] brace for ligamentous injury at T2 to
T3.  The patient will then follow up with the orthopedic
service in two to three weeks.  He is to call ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 108738**]
for an appointment.

As for the facial fractures, the patient will follow up at
the Plastic Surgery service at [**Telephone/Fax (1) **].  The patient did

He was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery team and taken to the
operating room immediately for diagnostic laparoscopy. On
laparoscopy, in the upper medial right anterior abdominal wall
there was evidence of an entry stab wound.  This was at the
medial aspect of the dome of the liver; the falciform ligament
was then penetrated with an open stab wounds from right to left.
 On the left side of the falciform on the surface of the liver
there was a visible approximately 2 cm in length stab wound on
the anterior surface of the liver which was not actively
bleeding.  Elevating the liver there was a small half cm stab
wound in the same trajectory visible and it was also not
bleeding. Postoperatively he was taken to the PACU where he was
noted with episodes of tachycardia and elevated blood pressure.
He was given IV Lopressor with improvement in his heart rate and
blood pressure. He was also transfused for a falling hematocrit
felt due to the blood loss associated with his injuries and the
operation. Once hemodynamically stable and was then transferred
to he regular nursing unit where he continued to progress.

He was given a regular diet on the second postoperative day and
was able tot tolerate this without any problems. [**Name (NI) **] was changed
to oral pain medications which were effective in controlling his
pain.

He was seen by Social Work for coping related to his injuries
and also due to the nature of his trauma. A safe discharge plan
was determined to be in place.

He was discharged to home and will follow up in the Acute Care
Surgery Clinic in the next couple of weeks.

A/P: [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with history of CAD, status post MI,
tachy-brady, status post pacemaker, CHF, diabetes type II, and
depression who sustained a left hip fracture after a fall at
rehab.

1. Left hip fracture: Upon medical clearance (unchanged EKG,
negative CXR, negative UA, normal PT/PTT, and correction of mild
hyponatremia and hyperkalemia), she underwent ORIF of her left
hip.  She was started on a 7 day course of prophylactic
antibiotics cefazolin and levofloxacin.  She was started on a 6
week course of enoxaparin 40 mg SC for DVT prophylaxis
post-operatively.  She should follow-up with orthopedics in 2
weeks upon discharge.

2. Hypotension: She had post-operative hypotension that was
attributed to hypovolemia given her peri-operative blood loss
resulting in a 6 point hematocrit drop.  She responded to fluid
bolus.  She remained hypotensive and required pressors.  A
cortisol stimulation test was borderline and she was started on
stress-dose steroids.  She required fluid boluses to maintain
her CVP and pressors to maintain her blood pressor.  On ICU day
3, she weaned off of the pressors.  Her stress dose steroids
were stopped after a 3 day course since her pressures were
stabilized and since she had a borderline cortisol stimulation
test.

3) Pain control: She was started on tramadol and acetaminophen
post-operatively for pain control.  She became somnolent and
unresponsive after 100 mg dose of tramadol.  She became
responsive after a 1 mg dose of naloxone.  Her tramadol dose was
adjusted to 25 mg [**Hospital1 **], which she tolerated well.  Her outpatient
gabapentin was also continued throughout the admission for
control of neuropathy in her feet.

3) Delirium: She had a exacerbation of delirium
post-operatively, which was most likely related to the
peri-operative Morphine and Fentanyl administration.  Her
neurological exam was grossly non-focal and a repeat head CT was
negative for acute event.
*
4) CAD/Afib/AS: Pre-operatively, her aspirin and isosorbide were
held.  Her Atacand was continued throughout the admission.  Her
sotalol was initially continued for rate control.  Her sotalol

He remained cyanotic despite bagging with good chest wall
movement. He was intubated. There was a significant amount of
blood noted from the hypopharynx. Apgars were 6 at 1 minute,
6 at 5 minutes and 7 at 10 minutes. He was admitted to the
Neonatal Intensive Care Unit for treatment of prematurity.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  Upon admission to the Neonatal
Intensive Care Unit: Weight 1.27 kilograms, 75th percentile,
length 37 cm, 50th percentile, head circumference 28 cm, 50th
percentile. General: Nondysmorphic preterm male, normal

Anterior fontanelle soft and flat, symmetric facial features,
palate intact. Neck supple without masses. Breach shaping to
the skull. Sutures. Mobile. Chest: Lungs coarse and crackly
with equal breath sounds bilaterally. Cardiovascular: Regular
rate and rhythm without murmur. Femoral pulses +2. Abdomen
soft, nondistended, no masses. Positive bowel sounds. GU:
Normal preterm male with bilaterally undescended testes.
Neurologic: Nonfocal examination and age appropriate tone.

HOSPITAL COURSE BY SYSTEMS INCLUDING PERTINENT LABORATORY
DATA:
1.  RESPIRATORY: [**Known lastname **] had profound hypoxemia requiring

    oscillatory ventilation with the subsequent diagnosis of
    pulmonary hypertension. [**Known lastname **] was treated with 2 doses of

    His best achievable arterial blood gas on maximum support

    Xrays were obtained to rule out pnumeothorax, and none was

    His increasing metabolic and respiratory acidosis remained
    refractory to treatment with sodium bicarbonate. His
    maximum ventilatory settings were a mean airway pressure
    of 20, a delta P of 44 and Hertz of 15.

2.  CARDIOVASCULAR: A cardiac echo was obtained showing a
    structurally normal heart with significant pulmonary
    hypertension with all right to left shunting. There was
    mildly decreased left ventricular function but still
    within normal limits. [**Known lastname **] required extensive pressor
    support in efforts to bolster his systemic perfusing
    pressure. His maximum pressor support was Dopamine at 20
    mcg per kilo per minute and dobutamine at 10 mcg per
    kilogram per minute. Following an episode of severe
    bradycardia, less than 60 beats per minute requiring
    cardiac compressions at approximately 12 hours of life he
    was started on an epinephrine drip. His maximum
    epinephrine dosing was 1 mcg per kilo per minute. He had
    umbilical arterial and umbilical venous catheters placed
    which were documented in good position by x-ray. despite
    140 ml per kilo of volume expansion and the multiple
    pressor support, [**Known lastname **] had refractory hypotension with
    post ductal saturations greater than 40 mmHg tor
    differential from preductal saturations. At approximately
    6 A.M. on [**2147-4-26**] he had bradycardia to less than 60
    beats per minute. Cardiac compressions were initiated.
    The parents were called to the bedside and in the setting
    of the severe acidosis with a pH of 6.52, the bradycardia
    and hypotension, the decision was made to redirect care
    to comfort measures and the baby was extubated and held
    by the parents.

3.  FLUIDS, ELECTROLYTES AND NUTRITION: [**Known lastname **] was NPO and
    maintained on intravenous fluids. His total fluid intake
    was approximately 100 cc per kilo per day. He was started
    on parenteral nutrition. His serum electrolytes were a
    sodium of 145, a potassium of 3.8, chloride of 108 and

4.  INFECTIOUS DISEASE: [**Known lastname **] was evaluated for sepsis upon
    admission to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. The white
    blood cell count was 11,400 with a differential of 9%
    polymorphonuclear cells, 1% band neutrophils, 74%
    lymphocytes. A blood culture was obtained prior to
    starting intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin.

5.  HEMATOLOGICAL: Hematocrit at birth was 47.3%. Hematocrit
    was rechecked due to the inability to adequately
    oxygenate and the noted placental abruption at birth.
    Repeat hematocrit was 12 hours of life was 43.8% with a

6.  NEUROLOGICAL: [**Known lastname **] had a normal neurological examination
    prior to his need for muscle relaxation and narcotic
    administration for sedation.

7.  SOCIAL: As previously noted, [**Known lastname **] had a terminal
    bradycardic event that led to redirection of care to
    comfort measures. His parents were present at the bedside

    his death. Autopsy permission was obtained. The infant

Admission Date:  [**2157-8-21**]       Discharge Date:  [**2157-8-30**]

Date of Birth:   [**2136-12-21**]       Sex:  M

Service:

CHIEF COMPLAINT:  Status post all-terrain vehicle
accident/crash.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 20-year-old
male status post all-terrain vehicle at roughly 40 miles per
hour.  The patient fell down an embankment which was about 40
feet down.  The patient did have positive loss of
consciousness and does not remember the accident.

The patient presented to the Emergency Department with
tachycardia and hypotension and was given 2 liters of
intravenous fluids and one unit of packed red blood cells.
X-rays at that time showed an open pelvic fracture.   A sheet
was placed around the pelvis and secured.  A CT scan of the
head was negative.  Lumbar spine films showed a spinous
process fracture.  Abdominal CT showed a small splenic
laceration, and the pelvic films showed multiple fractures of
the sacrum with a surrounding hematoma.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  None.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Status post left hip repair for a
hockey injury roughly seven years ago.

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:  None.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient occasionally drinks alcohol; one
to two drinks per week.  He denies use of tobacco and works
as a heavy machinery operator.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON PRESENTATION:   Initial physical
examination revealed pulse was 115, blood pressure was 77/57,
respiratory rate was 18, oxygen saturation of 100% on room
air.  In general, comfortable with pain medications.  Clear
to auscultation bilaterally.  His heart had a regular rate
and rhythm.  The abdomen was soft, nontender, and
nondistended.  The left hip showed some swelling and
ecchymosis.  The pelvis was very tender.  Rectal was within
normal limits with good rectal tone and guaiac-negative.  The
patient had 2+ femoral pulses, dorsalis pedis, and posterior
tibialis pulses.  The patient also had bilateral 2+ radial
pulses.

PERTINENT LABORATORY DATA ON PRESENTATION:  White blood cell
count was 18.9, hematocrit was 35, platelets were 213.  Blood
urea nitrogen was 19, creatinine was 0.2.  PT was 15.4, PTT
was 23.4.  Fibrinogen was 136.  Urinalysis showed large
blood, greater than 50 red blood cells.  Initial blood gas
revealed 7.33/44/279/24/-2.

RADIOLOGY/IMAGING:   A chest x-ray was negative.

Pelvis showed an open-book pelvic fracture.

A CT of the abdomen showed a small splenic laceration and a
small left kidney laceration.

HOSPITAL COURSE:   On day one, the patient required two more
units of packed red blood cells for a decrease in hematocrit.
The patient continued to have a decreasing hematocrit after
the two units and was given another three units of packed red
blood cells.

On hospital day two, the patient continued to be monitored in
the Intensive Care Unit setting.  The patient was in stable
condition but continued with tachycardia and decreasing
hematocrit.

It was decided that the patient would have an angiogram to
evaluate for the possibility of an arterial bleed.  The
patient was taken down to angiography.  An ultrasound of the
pelvic vessels demonstrated no arterial bleed.

On [**8-23**], which was hospital day three, the patient was
brought to the operating room by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 9694**] to have an
external fixation of the pelvis.  The patient had the
application of external fixation of the pelvis with closed
reduction of the open fracture.  He tolerated the procedure
well and was transported to the Postanesthesia Care Unit in
stable condition.

During the procedure, the wound was washed with copious
amounts of normal saline and roughly about 200 cc of hematoma
was drained, spontaneous relief of the left side of the
incision.

On postoperative day one, the patient continued to do well.
He was stable and was transferred to the floor.

On postoperative day five, the patient continued to have a
slow ooze requiring another two units of packed red blood
cells.  Orthopaedics was consulted again, who recommended
that the patient be stabilized medically, and they also
recommended the patient not go back to the operating room for
fixation of the posterior aspect of the pelvis due to the
multiple fractures and the chance of a infection following
the procedure.  The patient received two additional units and
subsequently had a stable hematocrit.

During the patient's stay on the floor, he had multiple
issues with pain medication; at which time an Acute Pain
Service consultation was called.  They recommended the use of
Percocet, Vioxx, and Motrin for breakthrough pain which
controlled his pain.  The patient also had his left lower
extremity fracture placed in a cast while he was on the
surgical floor.

The patient continued to do well following the stabilization
of his pelvic bleed, and on postoperative days 8, 9, and 10
he was out of bed to the chair comfortably.  At the end of
his hospital stay it was noted the patient had a slight
deformity of his left shoulder.  Films were taken which
showed a grade 3 separation of that joint.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 9694**] was
consulted once again regarding his shoulder, and his
recommendations included surgery as an outpatient following
this acute episode.  This would allow the patient to use
crutches with the shoulder as it is.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 9694**] also noted
that there would be no change in outcome from fixing his
shoulder now versus in six to eight months.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON DISCHARGE:  Temperature maximum
was 99.6, temperature current was 99.4, blood pressure
was 126/70, pulse was 100, respiratory rate 18, oxygen
saturation was 96% on room air.  6000 in and 2100 out.
Neurologically, he was alert and oriented times three.
Cardiovascular revealed a regular rate and rhythm.
Respiratory was clear to auscultation bilaterally.  The
abdomen was soft, nontender, and nondistended.  Extremities
were warm and soft with palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior
tibialis pulses.  The incision was intact without erythema.
Views of the pelvis on [**2157-8-29**] showed stable
external fixation with good alignment.  Left shoulder film
showed a grade 3 shoulder separation.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:  At this time, it was decided that the
patient was stable enough to be discharged to rehabilitation
services.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1.  Status post all-terrain vehicle crash with multiple
injuries.
2.  Open pelvic fracture; status post external fixation.
3.  Status post left closed ankle fracture.
4.  Grade 3 left should separation.

MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE:
1.  Tylenol 650 mg p.o. q.4-6h. as needed.
2.  Benadryl 25 mg p.o./intravenously q.4-6h. as needed.
3.  Protonix 40 mg p.o. every 24 hours.
4.  Colace 100 mg p.o. b.i.d.
5.  Bisacodyl 10 mg p.o./p.r. q.d. as needed.
6.  Lovenox 30 mg subcutaneous q.12h.
7.  Vioxx 25 mg p.o. b.i.d. (times 14 days).
8.  Hydromorphone 6 mg p.o. q.3.h as needed.
9.  Morphine 2 mg intravenously/subcutaneous as needed.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1.  Treatments included Venodyne while the patient is in bed
or sitting in a chair.
2.  Please check his hematocrit every three days to verify
the stability of his hematocrit and pelvic bleed.
3.  The patient was to have the cast on his left lower
extremity remain on for three to four weeks.
4.  The patient should call Dr.[**Name (NI) 9695**] office in roughly
three to four weeks regarding followup.
5.  The patient was also to be nonweightbearing on the left
lower extremity and full weightbearing on the right lower
extremity.
6.  The patient was to continue with Physical Therapy and
Occupational Therapy.  For the first week, the patient should
only be out of bed to the chair with full weightbearing on
his right lower extremity.  As the week progresses, the
patient may ambulate with crutches.

DISCHARGE FOLLOWUP:
1.  The patient was to follow up with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] in the
Trauma Service in one to two weeks.
2.  The patient was also to follow up Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 9694**] in the
[**Hospital 9696**] Clinic in four weeks; his telephone number
is [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4301**].

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:   Discharge condition was good and
stable.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  To rehabilitation services.

DISCHARGE DIET:  Regular diet.

DISCHARGE ACTIVITY:  Physical Therapy restricted activity
with nonweightbearing status on the left lower extremity and
full weightbearing status on the right lower extremity.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. [**Known lastname **] presented to the [**Hospital1 18**] on [**2167-8-12**] via transfer from
[**Hospital6 5016**] after being involved in a motorcycle crash.
 She was evaluated by the trauma and orthopaedic surgery
services.  She was found to have a left tibia plateau and shaft
fracture, a left foot metatarsal fractures, and a right elbow
fracture.  She was admitted, prepped, and then taken to surgery
by orthopaedics.  She underwent and ORIF of her tibia shaft and
plateau fractures.  She tolerated the procedure well and was
then taken to the trauma ICU for further care.  On [**2167-8-13**] she
was weaned and extubated.  She was transferred to the floor but
unfortunately her uncooperative behavior and nursing
requirements were too high and she was transferred back to the
Trauma ICU for care.  On [**2167-8-14**] and on [**2167-8-15**] she was
transfused with 2 units of packed red blood cells due to acute
post operative anemia each day.  On [**2167-8-15**] she was also
intubated to acute agitation, confusion, and poor respiratory
status.  On [**2167-8-16**] she was transfused with 4 units of packed red
blood cells due to acute post operative anemia.  On [**2167-8-17**] she
self extubated.  On [**2167-8-18**] she was transferred to the floor.  On
[**2167-8-19**] she returned to the OR for and ORIF of her left [**1-18**]
metatarsal fractures and closed reduction of her right elbow
with external fixator placement.  She tolerated the procedure
well.  On [**2167-8-24**] she returned to the operating room for I&D of
her left leg wound which required VAC placement due to extensive
debridement.  Cultures from the I&D grew enterococcus sensitive
to Vancomycin.  She was also seen by psychiatry to recommended
1:1 sitters and medication to help with agitation and confusion.
 On [**2167-8-28**] she returned to the operating room for an I&D with
VAC change which tolerated well.  On [**2167-9-3**] she returned to the
operating room for an I&D with VAC change, which she tolerated
well.  On [**2167-9-7**] she returned to the operating room for an I&D
with VAC change which she tolerated well.  On [**2167-9-9**] she fell
out of bed.  X-rays were done which showed no new fracture.  On
[**2167-9-10**] she was taken to the operating room by plastic surgery
for a split thickness skin graft on her left tibia.  She
tolerated the procedure well, was extubated, transferred to the
recovery room, and then to the floor.  On [**2167-9-12**] a PICC line
was placed for long term antibiotics and due to poor peripheral
access.    On [**2167-9-15**] her distal radial external fixator was
broken.  The external fixator remained intact and was supported
by an orthoplast splint.  On [**2167-9-17**] her VAC over her split
thickness skin graft was removed and revealed that the graft had
took well.  On [**2167-9-24**] her right elbow external fixator was
removed along with some K-wires from her left foot.  On [**2167-10-5**]
the remaining K wires were removed from her left foot.  The rest
of her hospital stay was uneventful with her lab data and vital
signs within normal limits, and her pain controlled.  She is
being discharged today in stable condition.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the MICU [**2147-6-23**] with fever and
hypotension.  She was started on vanc/levo/flagyl and a
subclavian TLC was placed.  CXR was taken which demonstrated
retrocardiac opacity.  She was started on levaphed for pressure
of 90/42.  She received HD for her ESRD.  The fever and
hypotension were considered to possibly represent sepsis,
although there was also consideration of fever in the context of
chronically low BP.  Sputum has remained NGTD.  The patient was
observed one examination to have a foot ulcer.  Endometritis was
considered.  However, the most likely etiology was considered
the patient's dialysis catheter which was replaced at the same
site on admission.  The patient grew out serratia narcessans and
coag negative staph and was started on a course of levoquin and
gentamycin.  On [**6-26**], the tunnelled catheter was removed.  on [**6-27**]
the patient's central line was changed to a dialysis catheter
and she was dialyzed through it.  On discharge, the patient has
received seven days of levoquine and seven days of vancomycin
and will receive another seven days of each, levoquine PO and
vancomycin at dialysis.  The patient has been abectermic for 3
days, excepting gram positive rods believe to represent
contimination.  She has been afebrile for four days and her
white blood cell count has decreased from a maximum of 25.3 to
6.6 today.  She has been normotensive for several days.  She
will next receive dialysis tommorow where she will be dosed with
vancomycin.  Throughout her admission she received wound care
for her old foot ulcer by podiatry; she should continue to
receive wet to dry dressings on discharge.  She continues to
need OBGYN followup on her history of vaginal bleeding; she will
be given the number for the [**Hospital **] clinic to make an appointment.
 She was full code throughout her stay here.

Brief Hospital Course:
60 year old woman with history of auto immune mediated myeltiis
presenting with headache now with LP suggestive of early
bacterial meningitis vs aseptic meningitis admitted to [**Hospital1 **] for
antibiotic desensitization.

Acute Issues:
# Meningitis: On admission she had nuchal rigidity and headache
with symptoms evolving following exposure to IVIG, with
suspected adverse reaction to IVIG. Additionally, aseptic
meningitis following IVIG infusion has been reported. Her
initial LP could also reflect an early bacterial meningitis vs
viral meningitis. Although the gram stain was negative,
antibiotic initiation was recommended by the infectious disease
team, as some organisms such as neisseria can be slow to
culture. She received IV acyclovir, vancomycin, bactrim and
underwent desensitization to ceftriaxone. HSV PCR was requested
from OSH LP. She did develop throat swelling at higher dose of
ceftriaxone and required IV  solumedrol, benadryl and
famotidine. The patient subsequently tolerated ceftriaxone. She
was transferred to the floor on HOD 2. HSV PCR was negative at
OSH and thus acyclovir was discontinued. The ID team recommended
a repeat LP and this was done. It showed no signs of infectious
etiology with only 7 WBCs, no organisms or polys, and negative
gram stain. Antibiotics were discontinued at this time. The
patient was observed for 12 hours after and was without symptoms
or fever. She was discharged home with the thought that the
meningitis was aseptic and secondary to adverse reaction to
IVIG.

# Autoimmune mediated myelitis: Pt had acute flare of her
myeltis with IVIG given. She had improvement of myelitis
symptoms with IVIG but development of nausea and headache
subsequently as well as aseptic meningitis picture, most likely
an adverse reaction to IVIG. This was discussed by her
neurologist given that she is planned for weekly IVIG. The
patient was scheduled to follow up with her outpatient
neurologist Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 9449**] for further treatment.

Chronic Issues:
# Asthma: home advair was continued.

# Glaucoma: continued eye drops

# h/o seziures: home clonazepam 1.5mg [**Hospital1 **] with additional 1 mg
dose at 2 pm was continued.

Transitional Issues:
- Patient will follow up with outpatient neurologist regarding
futher care of autoimmune myelitis.
- CSF culture pending.
- Blood cultures pending.

HISTORY OF THE PRESENT ILLNESS:  [**Known firstname **] [**Known lastname 28980**] is a male,
71-years old with a past medical history notable for a left
pneumonectomy for lung cancer in [**2139**]; tuberculosis;
pericarditis with tamponade in early [**2149**], which is a
questionable diagnosis; hypertension; hypothyroidism; and
diabetes mellitus.  He presented with left sided chest pain
with radiation into his left arm.  The patient began feeling
sick one week prior to admission with upper respiratory
tract-like symptoms.  He had a cough productive of yellow
sputum, fatigue, fever and chills.  The day, prior to
admission, the patient developed substernal 9 out of 10 chest
pain with radiation into his left arm, approximately 10 p.m.
the day prior to admission.  On the morning of admission, the
patient, at 4 a.m. took some Percocets, which were the only
thing, which relieved the pain.  The pain was associated with
diaphoresis and some mild dyspnea.  There were no other
symptoms.

Over the course of the day during the 13th, the patient no
longer felt chest pain, but did feel fatigue and his family
noted that he did not look well.  He was brought to the
emergency department for further evaluation.

Upon arrival to the emergency department, the patient had no
complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, or was
diaphoretic.

In the emergency department, the patient was evaluated.
Heart rate was 110, blood pressure 96/50.  He was breathing
at a rate of 14 on two liters nasal cannula, saturating 98%.
His physical examination was significant for no JVP above the
clavicle, no carotid bruits.  He had an S1 and S2.  He had an
S3, as well as an S4.  Abdominal examination was benign.
Lungs:  left sided, no breath sounds, no air entry, dull to
percussion.  Right side demonstrated coarse breath sounds
throughout, mostly on expiration.  Extremity examination
revealed 1+ pulses throughout, warm extremities times four.

Emergency department EKG demonstrated sinus tachycardia with
Q-waves in V1 through V4 as the only notable finding.
Echocardiogram was performed in the emergency department,
which was significant for no pericardial effusion and
significant left ventricular dysfunction; however, it was a
poor study and ejection fraction could not be estimated.  He
had a normal chem 7 and normal CBC.  Cardiac enzymes were
significant for a CK of 2,245, MB fraction of 105, and
troponin I of greater than 50.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  The patient was admitted to the Coronary
Care Unit for close monitoring of hemodynamic instability
with low blood pressures and elevated heart rate.  The
[**Hospital 228**] hospital course is significant for the following:

Echocardiogram was done the day after admission, which
demonstrated an ejection fraction of 20%, anteroseptal and
anterior free-wall akinesis; lateral wall hypokinesis; with
all other segments of the left ventricle, which were
significant for hypokinesis.

The patient's pressures remained low during the course of his
hospital stay and on the night of the 14th, the patient was
started dopamine and dobutamine at different times and
stopped secondary to elevated heart rate.  He was treated
then with Neo to maintain a blood pressure in the 90s/60s.
The patient's chest x-ray at this time demonstrated no focal
infiltrate.  However, due to his productive cough of yellow
sputum, a white count of 11.2 and intermittent fevers, which
peaked out at 101, the patient was started on Ceftriaxone 1-g
q.d. for a seven-day course to treat a possible pneumonia.
As a result of the patient's continued hypotension and need
for Neo to support his blood pressure, the patient on [**12-17**]
was taken to the cardiac catheterization laboratory, as the
patient appeared to be in cardiogenic shock.  The
catheterization demonstrated no left main coronary artery
disease and LAD demonstrated 90% proximal disease, moderate
diffuse mid disease, no significant disease of the left
circumflex, and RCA demonstrated 90% mid long disease.  At
the time of the procedure, the patient was weaned off Neo.
Intra-aortic balloon pump was placed.  Other interventions
were significant for an LAD, which was stented with a 2.5-mm
x 13-mm Hepacode stent.  The LAD and the RCA were stented
with a 33-mm x 3.0-mm Hepacode stent.  In order to improve
flow, intracoronary Dilt was administered and TIMI 2 flow was
the only flow, which was able to be established.

The patient was started on Integrilin during the procedure,
as well as Plavix, and had been on Heparin and was maintained
on Heparin for intra-aortic balloon pump, as well as his
anterior akinesis.  The patient was also started on
dobutamine at the time that the balloon pump was placed while
in the cardiac catheterization laboratory.  The patient was
transferred back to the Coronary Care Unit for continued
monitoring.  Over the course of the next day, the patient's
blood pressure stabilized.  Dobutamine was turned off, and
the patient remained on the balloon pump for a total of 48
hours.  After 48 hours the balloon pump was weaned from a 1:1
ratio originally to a 1:3.  The patient's blood pressure was
tolerated well, off pressors and actually started on
Captopril 6.25 t.i.d. as the balloon pump was discontinued.

The remainder of the hospital course will be dictated by an
addendum from [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1104**].

The patient's medications will also be provided by [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **]
[**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1104**] at that time.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:  Acute myocardial infarction.

FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS:  Followup will be dictated by
[**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1104**].




                            [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], M.D.  [**MD Number(1) 2057**]

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt's a 19 yo F treated for pyelonephritis, hydronephrosis status
post percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement, C. difficile
infection, and anxiety.

Pyelonephritis:  Her pan-sensitive E. coli infection was treated
with intravenous ceftriaxone; this was switched to cefuroxime,
to complete a two week course of antibiotics.  She notes a
cipro/bactrim allergy.  She will pick up her antibiotic from the
Freecare Pharmacy.

Hydronephrosis:  She was found to have a left ureteral stone
with hydronephrosis.  She was seen by the urology team and
underwent percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement.  This tube
remains in place; she will follow-up with the urology team as
noted, and will undergo laser lithotripsy after her urology
follow-up.

C. Difficile infection:  Her treatment was complicated by C.
difficile infection.  She was treated with flagyl, with
improvement in her diarrhea.  She will continue to take flagyl
while she is on the cefpodoxime, and will complete an additional
two weeks of therapy after the course of cefpodoxime has been
completed.

Anxiety:  She has significant panic disorder, and has not
previously been treated.  During her hospitalization, she had
frequent episodes where she felt lightheadedness, dizziness,
chest/throat tightness, and impending doom; these resolved
spontaneously.  She was seen by the psychiatry consult team; we
offered Paxil, but the patient declined to initiate a new
medication at this time.  She reported hallucinations with
ativan; as such, her episodes were managed with benadryl.  She
will follow-up next week with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 10166**] to initiate outpatient
follow-up.

for FreeCare, and will pick up her medications from the FreeCare
Pharmacy.  She will follow-up as noted.

Brief Hospital Course:
89-year-old woman with PMH HTN, Afib, decubitus ulcers,
presenting with bradycardia, shortness of breath, hypotension,
and septic shock likely from a) gram positive cocci [**2-19**]
decubitus ulcers b) urosepsis c) pneumonia.
.
The patient initially was resuscitated with IVF's and started on
broad antibiotic coverage with vancomycin, ceftazadime, and
flagyl.  Central venous access was initiated to monitor CVP per
sepsis goal directed therapy guidelines.  The patient presented
with do not resuscitate / do not intubate advanced directives.
Patient was supported with oxygen by nasal cannulae.
Bradycardia was resolved with atropine and hypotension was
treated with dopamine iv infusion.
.
Family, including son and daughter, were notified and came to
the hospital.  Discussions were engaged regarding ulimate goals
of care.  The decision was made to provide comfort measures only
and to withdraw active treatment of ultimate pathology.
Pressors and antibiotics were discontinued, and within 45
minutes the patient passed secondary to cardiac arrest.
.
The patient was pronounced dead at 12:51pm and arrangements were
made for burial proceedings with the family.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 64 year-old female with a history of recent dental
procedure who presents with rapid progression of sepsis with
multiorgan failure
.
Plan:
# Sepsis - Thought most likely to be due to Toxic Shock
syndrome.  Patient intially had elevating Pressor requirement
with cold extremities.  No cultures grew microbes either here or
at [**Hospital3 7571**]hospital.  By day 2 of hospitalization she was
in fulminant DIC with multiple organ failure.  Her skin began to
necrose and peel away.  Her perioral area also became cyanotic
and necrotic.  By day 3 of hospital stay, family decided to make
patient CMO.  She was extubated and expired within 1 hour.
.
#. Hemorrhagic bullae:  Patient with nearly 50% of total surface
area involved
.
#. Metabolic acidosis: Profound acidosis in the setting of
elevated lactate with likely sepsis and some respiratory
compensation. Treated with bicarb without resolution.
.
#. Acute Renal Failure: Elevated BUN and creatinine.   Per
renal, she not a CVVH or HD candidate.
.
#. NSTEMI: Pt with elevated CK and troponin, EKG with
non-specific changes, consistent with NSTEMI, likely secondary
to shock and hypoperfusion.
.
#. Rhabdomyolysis: Elevated CK at [**Numeric Identifier 2596**].
.
#. Transaminitis: ALT/AST elevated; normal alk phos and T bili,
so likely related to shock liver.

CHIEF COMPLAINT:  Acute leukemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  This is a 20 year-old male with
no significant past medical history who was in his usual
state of health until eight days prior to admission when he
noticed some dysuria and frequency.  He also had noted
enlarging groin lymph nodes, which he thought was related to
a urinary tract infection.  He had denied fevers or sweats.
He had gone to his school's health center where he also had
some neck lumps.  He was given Bactrim for a ten day course.
About two days prior to admission the patient had a bowel
movement and was straining on the toilet.  He subsequently
noticed that a black eye developed over his right eye after
the bowel movement and then a blind spot developed about "5
degrees off to the right" in his right eye.  He then
presented to the [**Hospital3 **] Emergency Department where he
was found to have a white count of 430,000 with 94% blasts.
His platelet count was 40,000 and the patient did have a
normal head CT there.  He initially received some hydroxyurea
with Allopurinol to decrease the white count.  He was also
placed on Ceftazidime for a fever to 101.8 and neutropenia.
His white count did decrease to 296,000 on hydroxyurea.  He
was then transferred to [**Hospital1 69**]
for emergent leukophoresis and management of acute leukemia.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Undescended testes status post repair.

MEDICATIONS AT HOME:  Bactrim.

MEDICATIONS ON TRANSFER FROM [**Hospital3 **]:  1.  Ceftazidime 2
grams intravenous q 12.  2.  Allopurinol 600 mg po q day.  3.
Hydroxyurea 2 grams po b.i.d.  4.  Percocet prn.  5.  Ambien
prn.  6.  Zofran prn.  7.  Intravenous fluids.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient is an art student who lives in
[**Hospital1 3494**].  He has a girlfriend and a supportive social
network of friends.  [**Name (NI) **] drinks 12 to 24 beers a week.  He did
endorse some cocaine usage about weekly.  There is no history
of intravenous drug abuse.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON ADMISSION:  Temperature 97.6.  Blood
pressure 130 to 145/50 to 60.  Heart rate 71.  Respiratory
rate 11.  97% on room air.  In general, the patient is a
young healthy appearing male in no acute distress, lying in
bed with a right internal jugular catheter in place.  His
HEENT examination is significant for periorbital ecchymosis
over the right orbit with scleral hemorrhage evident in the
right eye.  His neck showed large approximately 8 cm nodes in
the anterior cervical region as well as submental cervical
nodes.  His lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally.
His cardiovascular examination was regular rate and rhythm
with no murmurs, rubs or gallops.  His abdomen was notable
for some splenomegaly, but was otherwise soft, nontender,
nondistended with positive bowel sounds.  His groin revealed
some inguinal adenopathy bilaterally as well as right
pressure dressing was intact with a Quinton catheter had been
for phoresis.  Extremities showed no pedal edema and warm and
well perfuse extremities without rash.  Neurological
examination reveals a central blind spot only in the right
eye with maintained peripheral vision.  His cranial nerves
are otherwise intact with motor examination revealing 5 out
of 5 strength in all four extremities.

LABORATORIES ON PRESENTATION FROM [**Hospital3 **]:  White blood
cell count [**Pager number **] with a hematocrit of 26.3, platelets of 30.
Chem 7 notable for a creatinine of 1.8 and a potassium of
2.4.  His LDH was elevated at 3950.  His alkaline phosphatase
was elevated at 231.  In addition, after several days in the
Intensive Care Unit laboratories upon transfer to Four
[**Hospital Ward Name 1950**] are as follows:  White blood cell count 0.8,
hematocrit 21.7, platelets 27, chem 7 was normal and notable
for a creatinine of 0.7, INR of 1.7, PT 15.9, PTT 26.7.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  1.  Acute leukemia:  Because of the high
white count of 430,000, the patient was transferred to [**Hospital1 1444**] for acute phoresis for
management of leukostasis.  The patient tolerated the
procedure well and did notice some improvement in breathing.
The patient stated he felt very anxious due to some tightness
in his chest.  He maintained O2 saturations in the low 90s on
room air and had to be placed on 2 liters.  He experienced
great improvement with phoresis, but also received a lot of
intravenous fluids.  He had O2 saturations on the fourth
hospital day in the 80s on 50% FIO2 face mask.  However,
after some diuresis the patient responded very well with
brisk urine output and room air sats of approximately 95%.
He was also started on Idarubicin and ARA-C based on his
peripheral smear and flow cytometry results.  This
demonstrated acute myelogenous leukemia of M4 type.  He was
put on Cefepime instead of Ceftazidime for initial fever and
neutropenia. On the second hospital day he did spike a
temperature greater then 101 and was recultured with
Vancomycin added on the regimen.  The patient had a good
response to chemotherapy and his white blood cell count
decreased.  There was no evidence of tumor lysis during his
hospital course in the Intensive Care Unit.  He did have
acute renal failure, which was thought due to lysis on
kidney, which could be a complication of his acute leukemia.
He had mild evidence for disseminated intravascular
coagulation, but he had no bleeding from any sites on his
body.  He was transfused with fresh frozen plasma and
cryoprecipitate as needed.

2.  Fever and neutropenia:  At this time the patient's blood
cultures have been entirely negative.  An initial blood
culture, which was showing a gram stain positive for gram
positive coxae was retracted due to negative confirmatory
test in the microbiology laboratory.  Therefore his
Vancomycin was discontinued and at the time of this
dictation the patient is still on Cefepime.  He has had no
further febrile episodes.

3.  Acute renal failure:  Again as stated the patient
presented with a creatinine of 1.8, which is felt to be due
to lysis on kidney.  He was aggressively hydrated and was not
started on a bicarbonate drip per renal recommendations
unless his phosphate had become very elevated.  His renal
failure resolved with aggressive hydration and was normal by
the time he was transferred to the Four [**Hospital Ward Name 1950**] Bone Marrow
Transplant Unit.

4.  Bleeding:  The patient did have some episodes of bleeding
with the placement of the right internal jugular catheter as
well as a right groin Quinton catheter for phoresis.  The
Quinton catheter was discontinued on the day prior to
transfer to Four [**Hospital Ward Name 1950**] as there was no further need for
phoresis.  Pressure was held as well as the pressure dressing
applied.  He experienced no bleeding complications from the
removal of the Quinton catheter.  The right internal jugular
vein catheter continued to do well and function well after
the patient's coagulation parameters became normal.

The rest of the [**Hospital 228**] hospital course will be dictated at
a later date as a discharge summary addendum.

proximal 80%, left circumflex proximal 70%, obtuse marginal I

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  Baby Girl [**Known lastname 1661**] was born at 32
and 1/7 weeks gestation and admitted to the NICU with
prematurity and respiratory distress. She was born at 10:42

P2 now 4 mother with an estimated date of confinement of
[**2114-8-12**].  Prenatal labs included blood type B positive,
antibody negative, RPR nonreactive, Rubella immune, HBSAG
negative, GBS unknown.  This pregnancy was notable for
mono/mono twin gestation, reportedly spontaneous, complicated
by early cord entanglement, prompting admission at 25 weeks
gestation. Mother was treated with betamethasone at that time
and had remained hospitalized with intensive monitoring. Some
signs of fetal distress have been noted over the past several
days although ultrasound had been reassuring. The patient
reached 32 weeks gestation and decision was made to proceed
with Cesarean delivery at that time, due to the increased
risks of complications. Mother had experienced occasional
preterm contractions but was not in labor. The membranes were
intact at delivery and the mother did not receive intrapartum
antibiotic prophylaxis. The maternal history was otherwise
non contributory and the family is intact.

At delivery, this infant emerged with good tone, cry and
required stimulation and blow-by oxygen only. Occasional
apnea was noted in the delivery room which required positive
pressure ventilation. The infant was brought to the NICU for
further management.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  Physical examination on admission
showed a birth weight of 1775 grams which is 50th percentile.
Head circumference of 30.5 cm which is 50th to 75th
percentile.  Length of 42 cm which is 25 to 50th percentile.
The infant was warm and dry, premature infant in mild to
moderate distress at rest.  Active with examination and
mildly reduced spontaneous activity. HEENT showed fontanel
soft and flat.  Nares normal. Intact palate.  Neck:  Supple,
no lesions.  Chest:  Coarse breath sounds, mildly aerated,
mild to moderate retractions, mild grunting. Work of
breathing less with CPAP.  Cardiac:  Normal rate and rhythm,
no murmur.  Abdomen soft, no hepatosplenomegaly, no mass, 3
vessel cord, quiet bowel sounds.  Genitourinary:  Normal
female, patent anus.  Femoral pulses 2+.  Extremities, hips,
back normal.  Neuro:  Appropriate tone, mildly reduced
activity. Moves all extremities well.

on admission to the NICU and remained on CPAP until [**2114-6-21**]

cannula oxygen. She subsequently transitioned to room air by

was started on caffeine citrate for apnea of prematurity on
[**2114-6-20**] and remains on caffeine citrate at this time. She
continues to have occasional apnea and bradycardiac episodes,
anywhere from 1 to 5 per day, typically mild self-resolved
spells.  Breath sounds are clear and equal and mild to slight

Cardiovascular:  The infant received a single normal saline
bolus for perfusion on admission to the NICU.  A murmur

Echocardiogram duct check was done at that time which showed

Fluids, electrolytes and nutrition: The infant was made

liters of Crystalloid in the Operating Room.
Postoperatively, the patient was noted to be hypoxic and
hypotensive requiring Neo-Synephrine for blood pressure
support, and then nine hours postoperatively, CT scan
angiogram found to have large flow obstructing right
pulmonary artery embolus and a smaller left lower lobe and
lingular emboli.  The patient's pulmonary emboli was lysed
with tissue plasminogen activator and removed by suction
thrombectomy with good affect.

placed.  He was intubated for approximately 48 hours with

then.  He was heparinized postoperatively, requiring
inordinately high doses of heparin up to 2500 units per hour

experience severe pain not relieved by medication, increased

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do
not operate heavy machinery or drink alcohol when taking these
medications. As your pain improves, please decrease the amount

you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener
(e.g., colace) as needed to prevent this side effect.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your
surgeon or your primary physician.

6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may get the wound wet or
take a shower starting 5 days after surgery, but no baths or
swimming for at least 4 weeks. No dressing is needed if wound
continues to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need
to be removed will be taken out by a visiting nurse at 2 weeks
after your surgery.

7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your
follow-up appointment at 4 weeks.

bradycardia during labor. It resolved with repositioning.
However, at the onset of final stage of labor and pushing,
sustained fetal bradycardia to 60-70 was noted that
eventually prompted an emergent cesarean section delivery.
Onset of bradycardia was approximately 11 minutes prior to
delivery. No sepsis risk factors were noted and labor was
otherwise reportedly uncomplicated. At delivery the infant
emerged stunned requiring vigorous stimulation, as well as
positive-pressure ventilation with a bag and mask. Tone and
respiratory effort gradually improved. Heart rate remained
good at 100 throughout. By 10 minutes of life, the infant was
breathing spontaneously but had overall decreased tone and
activity and was noted to have increased work of breathing.
The infant was subsequently brought to the NICU receiving
facial CPAP therapy. Apgar scores were 4, 7 and 7.

cm, length 40.5 cm. Initial temperature is 100.3,
subsequently normalizing at 99.2. Heart rate in the 140s.

greater than 95% on room air. The infant was well-developed
with steadily improving spontaneous activity. Skin was warm
and dry. Lungs were coarse with poor aeration that also
improved rapidly. Initial grunting and retractions were noted
that resolved within the first 1-2 hours of life. Heart exam
was regular rate and rhythm without murmurs. Abdomen was soft
without hepatosplenomegaly. Femoral pulses were 2+. Profusion
was mildly reduced. Tone was initially increased with mild
jitteriness.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
1. Respiratory: The infant was noted to have mildly
    increased work of breathing on admission to the NICU,
    although oxygen saturations remained greater than 95% in
    room air throughout. Respiratory status gradually
    improved and within 1-2 hours of life, the infant was
    breathing comfortably in room air. No further
    respiratory issues were noted throughout hospitalization
    in the NICU. A chest x-ray was obtained and this was
    largely clear with mild streaking consistent with
    retained fluid.  No pneumothorax was noted.
2. Cardiovascular: The infant remained hemodynamically
    stable with appropriate vital signs throughout
    admission. One normal saline bolus was given on
    admission for decreased profusion with improvement.
3. FEN: Initial D-stick was greater than 100. The infant
    was initially started on maintenance IV fluids at D10W
    at 60 ml/kg/day. By approximately 10 hours of life, the
    infant's status had steadily improved and the infant was
    begun on ad lib oral feedings. The infant fed well
    taking Enfamil 20, 30-40 ml per feed and IV fluids were
    discontinued. At the time of transfer, the infant
    continues to feed well with stable blood sugars off of
    IV fluids. Of note, cord blood gases revealed a pH of
    7.00. initial arterial blood gas on admission to the

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. [**Known lastname 77230**] is an 87F with a PMH s/f chronic systolic HF (EF
30%), afib off coumadin, with baseline home O2 requirement who
presents with acute worsening of dyspnea and new oxygen
requirement.

1)Respiratory distress: Likely CHF exacerbation given Chest
X-ray findings. She is normally on 2L of O2 at home, which
increased to 6L during her hospital stay. She received 160mg IV
Lasix on the floor with 2L of urine output. In the MICU, she
received an additional 80mg IV. Cardiac enzymes were negative.
Her oxygen requirements continued to improve with diuresis. On
the day of discharge, she was at baseline of 2 liters and
satting at 90-91%. She had been adequately diuresed and it was
felt that low baseline saturations were likely secondary to
bibasilar atelectasis as identified on Chest CT. Her home Lasix
dose was increased and she was discharged on 60mg PO BID, (vs
40mg PO BID on admission). Clinically she appeared euvolemic at
the time of discharge. Discharged with instruction to encourage
ambulation, incentive spirometry to improve air movement.

2)Acute on chronic renal failure: Baseline Cr 1.3-1.5; elevated
to 2.0 on admission.
Her Cr was monitored closely and her medications were renally
dosed. Her creatinine stabilized at 1.7 and it was felt that
this liekly represents new baseline creatinine for her.

3)Chronic systolic/diastolic heart failure: Patient was diuresed
as above. Losartan was held in light of elevated creatinine, but
restarted prior to discharge. She was continued on beta-blocker.
ECHO showed improvement of global systolic function with EF of
50-55%, improved from [**2193-1-10**] Echo with 30% EF.

4)HTN: She was continued on home regimen of Amlodipine and
Metoprolol.

5)Atrial fibrillation: s/p pacemaker. She is not on
anticoagulation as an outpatient. She was continued on
beta-blocker for rate control. Her outpatient PCP at [**Name9 (PRE) 15303**]
rehab was contact[**Name (NI) **] and it was recommended that anticoagulation
be initiated for atrial fibrillation.He will investigate why
this was not previosuly done and consider starting. No
anticoagulation was started while inpatient.

6)Dementia: Continued on Aricept and Namenda.

7)Hypothyroidism: Continued on Levothyroxine.

8)DM type II: Patient is on Glipizide as outpatient; this was
held in light of her acute renal failure. She was placed on an
insulin sliding scale with good blood sugar control. Prior to
discharge, glipizide was restarted at home dose.

9)Gout: Continued on Allopurinol which was renally dosed.

10)Depression: Continued on Paxil.
